abstract.p: Future of Arliss, HBO's five-year-old comedy about sports agent, remains uncertain; producer Robert Wuhl is trying to keep it alive (S)

block.p: The only HBO series apparently unsure of its future is ''Arliss,'' the five-year-old comedy about a sports agent. Robert Wuhl, who produces, stars in and writes for the show, is also its unrelenting advocate. On at least two earlier occasions he lobbied hard to keep the show alive and suceeded.

Now, having been paired with the ultra-hot ''Sex and the City,'' ''Arliss'' has seen its ratings improve about 7 per cent for the season that just ended. Mr. Wuhl said in a telephone interview that HBO had ordered him to write six more scripts. ''It may be because of the possible strike'' of actors and writers, Mr. Wuhl said. ''This is a way to get us started early.'' But whatever the reason, he is eager to keep his show going.

''I think we bring a new audience after 'Sex and the City,' '' he said, 'though we've been keeping more and more of their viewers.''

An HBO spokesman said that ''Six Feet Under,'' if it becomes a series, may get a shot at filling the half-hour behind ''Sex and the City,'' which may have some impact on the future of ''Arliss.'' But Mr. Albrecht has said he would like to keep expanding the number of series on HBO, which may mean more seasons for all the current entries.
